consent.title: Welcome to our study
content: In this study, we are interested in studying how people's uncertainty when observing and reason about other agents. You will read 20 scenarios and answer questions about the agents. The experiment should take 20 minutes in total.
You will be compensated for your time at the end of the study at 15 dollars / hour.
What should I know about a research study?
• Whether or not you take part is up to you.
• You can choose not to take part.
• You can agree to take part and later change your mind.
• Your decision will not be held against you.
• Your refusal to participate will not result in any consequences or any loss of benefits that you are otherwise entitled to receive.
• You can ask all the questions you want before you decide.
For any questions, please feel free to contact lanceying@mit.edu

content.value: For each scenario in this study, we are interested in measuring how people assign probability in their judgments. You will answer the questions by indicating your uncertainty over the answer options.
You will either use an interactive panel to draw a histogram below:
Or answer your probabilistic judgment using a linear scale:

content.alt: Example of linear scale response interface
content.caption: Linear scale for probability judgments

content.value: You will first go through two questions as part of the tutorial. Then you will proceed to the main experiment.

After you answer the question, we will ask you to modify the scenario by giving some additional background information which would change how you would respond to the question above. For example, consider the following example:
Alice is going out for lunch. There is a shop A, which is 3 minutes away, and shop B, which is 6 minutes away. You observe Alice going for shop A. Which shop does Alice like best?
You may be uncertain about Alice's preference, because although she went to shop A, it may be due to the fact that it is a closer option.
Now you are asked to modify the scenario. What information, if true, would change your judgment?
• "Today is Sunday and shop B is closed"
• "Shop A is having a massive discount today!"
You will next go through a test run as part of the tutorial. Then you will proceed to the main experiment.
Now, let's try a simple test scenario. This will help you get familiar with the interface before starting the actual study.
